instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> came in with no sign of damage or liquid damage with no power and no light on MagSafe Charger.
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 16.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.3V.
Diode mode reading full short on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Applied IPA on underside of board, injected 1.8V 1A power on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and noticed the SMC (<CHIP>U5000</CHIP>) was heating up first. Specifically heating up in 1 specific spot on the SMC.

Is it safe to say that there is an internal short in the SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message:
You can increase injected voltage untill 3.5V and get higher current.
In fact, if you get 3V/2A (as example) should be good enough to detect if only SMC heats.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message: Inspect super closely to make sure it?s not a cap by the SMC. But yeah very likely the case. Remove it and see if short clears. Also make SURE PPBUS and PPVRTC are not also short once you remove the SMC to avoid wasting time. Sometimes I?ve seen the SMC shorting cause all of them to short to ground and kill the CPU. Not often, but it can happen. I would assume if the SMC is short this will be an easy one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message:
Thank you for the replies. I injected 3V 2A and only could find SMC heating up. I then removed the SMC and confirmed short is now gone. PPBUS and PPVRTC are not shorted with SMC removed, so it looks like my culprit is the SMC. I have never replaced one before, but just to make sure, all I really need is a stencil and a donor board to pull one from, correct?

Thanks again for all the advice.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message:
Sometime can be soldered even without reballing it; re-using rest of solder on the board pads.
However, I do NOT recommend this method.

I use 0.35mm to reball and sometime I placed them one by one, at hand (aprox 150).
Remember to take it form donor board, same model.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message: Yep reball as 2informaticos said. Must come from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board. I?d order 2-3 just to make sure you get a good SMC for the repair

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message: It took awhile to get an SMC stencil and 2 donor boards, but I went ahead and replaced the SMC, get green ling on magsafe and all S5 rails are present, but now device only turns in SMC bypass mode. All rails are present in SMC bypass mode. Does this mean the replacement SMC is a dud? If so, I have another one I can reball.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message: Likely bad SMC. Should work with a good SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message:
If start in SMC bypass, you must check all SMC sensors first.
Could be bad SMC also, but discard the sensors issue first.
Do you get correct <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message: I replaced the SMC again with another one from a donor board before I saw your replay 2informaticos. The board is still doing the same thing, so I am looking into the sensors, now. I have 3.3V on <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message: All the SMC sensors appear to be present. I plugged board into LVDS port and performed an SMC bypass, I get 1.8 on CPU VCORE, but no post. I am starting to think this may be a dead CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message: Doesn't post on SMC bypass now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message: I get fan spin and all power rails present. It originally slipped my mind to hook up board to a LVDS and see if it even posts. When i installed board back into macbook housing, and device has fan spin that restarts every 10 seconds. it appears it doesn't post or chime in SMC bypass mode. I've yet to experience a dead CPU, but from all the research in the forums, this sounds like all the symptoms of a dead CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message:
Very possibly dead CPU, but you can try to discard other options.
Now the board turns on in normal mode, as in SMC bypass too?
Did you install correct SMC (same donor board)?
Try new BIOS, just in case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message: This is true. The board turns on in both normal and SMC bypass mode. I an smc from the exact same board. Twice just to be sure I didn't get a dud SMC. When installing a new bios, do I have to pair it to the ME first before testing, or can I swap one from the donor board just to see if it even posts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> short in SMC
threads.message:
You need to test with clean ME.
Search the forum, few files are available...
